The key word, again, is "communications," not "programming."
The same approach holds true for television.
X am not suggesting that the informational-reportorial functions
should be ignored. On the contrary, they have distinct, significant
roles to play as essential parts of the total picture. What I am
saying is that communications should not be limited to informing¬
reporting, as seems to be the case in recommendations, discussions
and actions thus far. The burden seems to have been placed largely
on broadcast stations, especially commercial stations, for the pro¬
duction of such programs and materials, and though the stations and
networks should not be relieved of such responsibility, neither should
